elements.title: Niederdollendorf stone (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Niederdollendorf stone (pictured), the Grésin plaque, and the Landelinus buckle are each controversially conjectured to depict a pagan-inspired Jesus Christ?

elements.title: Gonzalo Brenes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that composer Gonzalo Brenes was a politician in the National Assembly of Panama and served for seven years as Panama's secretary of culture?

elements.title: 1961 Pittsburg State Gorillas football team (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the undefeated 1961 Pittsburg State Gorillas football team shut out seven opponents, featured four All-Americans, and won three national championships?

elements.title: Cathy Merrick (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Cathy Merrick was the first woman to be elected grand chief of the Assembly of Manitoba Chiefs?

elements.title: Ultimate X-Men (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Maystorm, a character from Ultimate X-Men, was initially created for a variant cover for the comic X-Men?

elements.title: Mike Veeck (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Mike Veeck's baseball promotions include Disco Demolition Night, a game with no fans, and the world's largest pillow fight?

elements.title: schools in Wales in the 17th century (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a clergyman from London established 87 schools in Wales in the 17th century?

elements.title: Harold C. Hinton (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Harold C. Hinton was one of the only American academics under McCarthyism to study communist China?

elements.title: a Sainsbury's supermarket (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that South African president Jacob Zuma requested a tour of a Sainsbury's supermarket during his state visit to the United Kingdom in 2010?
